nodes.bodyText: maybe loadingSearchResult for more descriptive name?
loading should be set to false in case of an error
searchTermString = '' saves initialization in constructor
Not my Style ;)
For every key event, a server request is started. Maybe we could reduce that with rxjs debounce time if we do another implementation of how the search is triggered?
I think we are fine for now.

Another problem I see in this is, that with http you don't have a guarantee in which order the separate requests arrive - that could possibly lead to a wrong search result if one request is delayed for some networking reason

I defenetly see your point, but to be honest I think this is really an edge case and not critical. If I understood it correctly, we are supposed to focus on functionality during review. So in my opinion this is fine, as well.

I agree to @TobiasPr that we should optimize this at least a bit. I think a key based search is too much load on the server. I would prefer if the search is triggered when the user changes the focus of the field and when the user does not type for at least 3s (I guess this is what you refer to as debounce time).
Also the search should only be triggered if the user typed in at least 3 characters, otherwise you automatically get too many search results
All right. Then I will implement that.

I implemented, that the search only starts when the input field loses focus. It also has a debounce time of 1 sec. I tried it with 3 sec but thats way to much. In my opinion I would also remove 1 sec of debounce time, since you already have a delay since the user must actively leave the focus of the input. This ensures that you don't have too much traffic on the server.
I implemented that the search works when the user inserted at least 3 character or none.
this method is used by a lot of other methods. Are you sure it's save to do the changes you did?
Quite stupid that I did not check that!
Ich baue das selber in meinen nächsten Commit ein.

nodes.bodyText: Let's stay with the default value here. I increased this recently and this should be fine (even if it was specified differently in the GitHub issue), except we run into performance problems
